SEARCH
Package gw.api.web.media

Interface MediaImageObject

All Known Subinterfaces:
MediaImageExifObject, MediaImageWithThumbObject
All Known Implementing Classes:
SimpleMediaImageExifObject
public interface MediaImageObject
An implementation of MediaImageObject represents a binary object to be displayed either in a gallery or as a single image. This might be a video, an image or something else. A media image object has a set of required properties which it certainly needs to function properly and optional properties having which will give it more features and functions. There could be 2 types of media objects: url based and input stream based. One of them must be provided.

    getObjectFit()
    Optional Specifies how a media should be resized to fit its container.

    Required/Optional An url pointing to the media source.

  • Method Details

    • getAltText

      String getAltText()
      Optional And alt text for the media

    • getObjectFit

      ObjectFit getObjectFit()
      Optional Specifies how a media should be resized to fit its container.

    • getUrl

      String getUrl()
      Required/Optional An url pointing to the media source. If this property is null then an input stream is required

    • getInputStream

      InputStreamSupplier getInputStream()
      Required/Optional InputStream to read a binary data from This property is required if the url is null and is ignored if it is not

    • getBadgeLabel

    • getBadgeStyle

      Optional Style for the label

    • getImageStyle

      ImageStyle getImageStyle()
      Optional How the image is going to be stylized.

    • getContentType

      String getContentType()
      Required/Optional This is required if the media object is input stream based. In that case the server needs what type of headers it needs to issue so a user would properly download the object,

    • getFileSize

      long getFileSize()
      Optional The size of the media object in bytes

    • getFileName

      String getFileName()
      Optional The file name of the media object. This might be used when saving the object on a disk.
